text:
CHEST RADIOGRAPHS

HISTORY:  Metastatic disease with known pulmonary metastases, presenting with
fever and leukocytosis.

COMPARISONS:  Radiographs from ___ as well as CT of the abdomen
and pelvis from that same day.  Radiographs are also available from ___.

FINDINGS:  The lung volumes are low.  The cardiac, mediastinal and hilar
contours appear unchanged, allowing for differences in technique.  There are a
number of round nodular densities projecting over each upper lung, but more
numerous and discretely visualized in the left upper lobe, similar to prior
study.  However, in addition, there is a more hazy widespread opacity
projecting over the left mid upper lung which could be compatible with a
coinciding pneumonia.  Pulmonary nodules in the left upper lobe are also not
completely characterized on this study.  There is no pleural effusion or
pneumothorax.  Post-operative changes are similar along the right chest wall.

IMPRESSION:  Increasing left lung opacification which may reflect pneumonia
superimposed on metastatic disease, although other etiologies such as
lymphangitic pattern of metastatic spread could be considered.  CT may be
helpful to evaluate further if needed clinically.

HISTORY:  Leukocytosis, low-grade temperature, rule out focal infiltrate.

TECHNIQUE:  Portable semi-upright AP radiograph of the chest.

COMPARISON:  Multiple prior radiographs of the chest most recent ___
CT of the chest ___.

FINDINGS:

Lung volumes remain low.  There are innumerable bilateral scattered small
pulmonary nodules which are better demonstrated on recent CT.  Mild pulmonary
vascular congestion is stable.  The cardiomediastinal silhouette and hilar
contours are unchanged.  Small pleural effusion in the right middle fissure is
new.  There is no new focal opacity to suggest pneumonia.  There is no
pneumothorax.

IMPRESSION:

1. Low lung volumes and mild pulmonary vascular congestion is unchanged. 

2. New small right fissural pleural effusion.

3. No new focal opacities to suggest pneumonia.

EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)

INDICATION:  History: ___ with gastric cancer, port in place with 1 day of RUE
swelling.// evidence of DVT? Location of port

TECHNIQUE:  Single frontal view of the chest

COMPARISON:  None

FINDINGS: 

Right-sided Port-A-Cath terminates in the low SVC without evidence of
pneumothorax.  No focal consolidation is seen.  There is no pleural effusion
or pneumothorax.  Tiny pulmonary nodules seen on prior chest CTs were better
appreciated on CT, a more sensitive study.

IMPRESSION: 

Right Port-A-Cath terminates in the low SVC without evidence of pneumothorax.

INDICATION:
___ year old man with aortic stenosis, CAD, also status post left lower lobe
wedge resection for lung cancer..

COMPARISON:  Comparison is made to chest CT from ___ and chest
radiograph from ___.
TECHNIQUE
Frontal and lateral view of the chest.

FINDINGS: 

The cardiomediastinal silhouette is normal. There is pleural scarring at the
left lung base, compatible with postoperative changes from left lower lobe
wedge resection. A area of calcifications along the third anterior rib space
represents pleural plaque, as seen on prior chest CT. On the lateral view, a
density projecting along the aortic root may represent an additional calcified
pleural plaque or a pulmonary nodule. No focal consolidation. No pneumothorax.

IMPRESSION: 

Density projecting over the ascending aorta on lateral view represents either
a pleural plaque or a pulmonary nodule. The should be investigated further
with comparison to more recent chest CTs, or new chest CT study if non is
available.

Asbestos related pleural plaques, some calcified.

No evidence of pneumonia.

Postoperative changes from left lower lobe wedge resection.

NOTIFICATION:

CHEST, TWO VIEWS:  ___

HISTORY:  ___ male with altered mental status.  Question pneumonia.

FINDINGS:  PA and lateral views of the chest are compared to previous exam
from ___.  As on prior, there are low lung volumes.  There are
calcified pulmonary nodules seen in the right upper lung stable dating back to
___.  The lungs are clear of consolidation, effusion or
pneumothorax.  Cardiomediastinal silhouette is unchanged as are the osseous
and soft tissue structures.

IMPRESSION:  No acute cardiopulmonary process.

EXAMINATION:
Chest:  Frontal and lateral views

INDICATION:  History: ___ with chest pain  // PNA

TECHNIQUE:  Chest:  Frontal and Lateral

COMPARISON:  ___

FINDINGS: 

Patient is status post median sternotomy.  The inferior most sternotomy wire
is again seen to be fractured.  Lung volumes are relatively low.  There is
moderate pulmonary vascular congestion/edema.  More confluent focal opacity at
the right lung base may be due to volume overload, but pulmonary nodule or
consolidation is not excluded.  Recommend repeat after diuresis.  No large
pleural effusion or pneumothorax is seen.  Cardiac silhouette is enlarged.

IMPRESSION: 

Moderate pulmonary vascular congestion/edema.  More focal nodular opacity at
the right lung base could be due to volume overload, but pulmonary nodule or
consolidation is not excluded.  Recommend repeat chest radiographs after
diuresis.

Cardiomegaly.  No large pleural effusion.

INDICATION:  Lingular atelectasis seen on CT abdomen dated ___.  Concern
for metastasis.

COMPARISON:  With chest x-ray dated ___.

FINDINGS:  The lungs are normal in appearance.  There is no radiographic
evidence of atelectasis, pulmonary nodules, or pleural effusion.  The cardiac
and mediastinal contours are normal.

IMPRESSION:  Normal study.

INDICATION:    Preop

TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral

COMPARISON:  ___

FINDINGS: 

Left prepectoral dual lead pacemaker in-situ with the lead tips in the
appropriate positions.  Cardiomegaly.  No airspace consolidation.  No
suspicious pulmonary nodules or masses.  No pleural effusions.  No
pneumothorax.  Degenerative changes of the thoracic spine.

IMPRESSION: 

Cardiomegaly. No pneumonia.

EXAMINATION:
Chest:  Frontal and lateral views

INDICATION:  History: ___ with sob, hx testicular ca on chemotx// please eval
for acute abnormalities, fluid overload, infectious process

TECHNIQUE:  Chest:  Frontal and Lateral

COMPARISON:  ___

FINDINGS: 

Dual lead left-sided pacemaker is stable in position.  A right-sided
Port-A-Cath is seen, distal tip of the catheter not well seen due to
overlapping pacer leads, but likely courses at least into the distal SVC. 
There are low lung volumes, which accentuate the bronchovascular markings. 
Given this, there is slight prominence of the hila, stable compared to prior. 
No focal consolidation is seen.  Pulmonary nodules reported on chest CT from
___ better appreciated on CT, a more sensitive study.  There is
no pleural effusion or pneumothorax.  No pulmonary edema is seen.  Cardiac and
mediastinal silhouettes are stable.

IMPRESSION: 

No acute cardiopulmonary process.

EXAMINATION:  PA lateral chest radiograph.

INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with h/o Crohns on remicade with persistent
cough and f/u 6 mm upper lobe nodule// assess cough, f/u nodule

TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral

COMPARISON:  Reference is made to the prior chest radiograph dated ___ as well as ___.

FINDINGS: 

The lungs are clear without focal consolidation.  Pulmonary vasculature is
within normal limits without evidence of pulmonary edema.  There is no large
pleural effusion.  There is no pneumothorax.  Cardiac silhouette is normal. 
Better evaluated on the current exam, the previously described right upper
lobe opacity does not represent a pulmonary nodule but rather an azygos
fissure.

IMPRESSION: 

The previously described right upper lobe opacity does not represent a
pulmonary nodule but rather an azygos fissure.  This is a benign anatomical
variant and no further follow-up is recommended.

PA AND LATERAL CHEST ___ AT 2244 HOURS.

HISTORY:  Syncope.

COMPARISON:  None.

FINDINGS:  There are ill-defined somewhat elongated opacities extending into
the lateral aspects of the right upper lung.  More linear fine interstitial
lines are noted at the lung bases, particularly on the left.  Lung volumes are
diminished inferiorly.  There is mild aortic tortuosity.  The cardiac
silhouette is grossly within normal limits for size, though evaluation limited
by low lung volumes.  No definite effusion or pneumothorax is seen.  There is
a slight dextroconcave curvature of the mid and lower thoracic spine.

IMPRESSION:  Ill-defined densities laterally in the right upper lung of
indeterminate chronicity.  Diagnostic considerations include mucoid impaction
in the setting of bronchiectasis versus underlying pulmonary nodules. 
Conceivably early developing focal infiltrate may also account for this
appearance.

EXAMINATION:
Chest:  Frontal and lateral views

INDICATION:  History: ___ with rapidly progressive vasculitis// nodules, pna

TECHNIQUE:  Chest:  Frontal and Lateral

COMPARISON:  None.

FINDINGS: 

No focal consolidation is seen.  There is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
The cardiac and mediastinal silhouettes are unremarkable.  No pulmonary edema
is seen.

IMPRESSION: 

No acute cardiopulmonary process.  If clinical concern persists for small
pulmonary nodules, chest CT is more sensitive.

INDICATION:  History of end-stage renal disease.  Evaluate for evidence of
congestive heart failure.

COMPARISON:  None.

FINDINGS:  A single frontal portable radiograph of the chest was acquired. 
The heart is mildly enlarged.  There are diffuse interstitial opacities
radiating from the hila as well as Kerley B lines and vascular cephalization,
consistent with mild interstitial pulmonary edema.  A 15-mm nodular opacity
projects just superior to the right costophrenic angle.  The mediastinal
contours are normal.  The right hilus is bulbous in appearance.  There are no
pleural effusions.  No pneumothorax is seen.

IMPRESSION:

1.  Mild cardiomegaly with mild interstitial pulmonary edema.

2.  15-mm nodular opacity superior to the right costophrenic angle, possibly a
calcified pulmonary nodule.  Further assessment with conventional radiographs
should be performed once the patient's fluid status has normalized.

3.  Bulbous appearance of the right hilus should be reassessed on the same
conventional radiographs as recommended in impression point #2.

Findings and recommendations were discussed with Dr. ___ by Dr. ___ at
7:41 a.m. via telehpone on ___.

INDICATION:  ___ with CP// intrapulmonary process

TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral

COMPARISON:  Multiple prior chest radiographs, most recently ___.
Chest CT from ___

FINDINGS: 

Lungs are moderately well expanded.  Bibasilar opacities most suggestive
atelectasis, similar appearance to prior in ___.  No focal consolidation
to suggest pneumonia.  Biapical scarring is again noted with redemonstrated
right upper lobe pulmonary nodule which appears stable from multiple priors. 
Cardiomediastinal silhouette and hila are unremarkable.  Tortuous aorta.  No
pneumothorax or pleural effusion.

IMPRESSION: 

No acute process.

EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)

INDICATION:  History: ___ with chest pressure.  Assess for ptx

TECHNIQUE:  Portable AP chest

COMPARISON:  Multiple prior chest radiographs, most recently ___.

FINDINGS: 

Lung volumes are low.  Mild bibasilar atelectasis.  No focal consolidation is
seen.  Right upper lobe pulmonary nodule appears stable compared to multiple
prior exams.  No large pleural effusion or pneumothorax.  The
cardiomediastinal silhouette is within normal limits.

IMPRESSION: 

No acute intrathoracic process.

CHEST, TWO VIEWS:  ___ 

HISTORY:  ___ female with left-sided chest pain radiating down the
left arm.

COMPARISON:  Chest x-ray from ___ and chest CT from ___.

FINDINGS:  Frontal and lateral views of the chest.  Known bilateral pulmonary
nodules are better seen on chest CT.  Biapical scarring is again noted.  The
lungs are hyperinflated but clear of consolidation or effusion.  Linear left
basilar opacity suggestive of atelectasis or scarring.  The cardiomediastinal
silhouette is within normal limits.  No acute osseous abnormality is detected.

IMPRESSION:  No acute cardiopulmonary process.  Continued followup of
pulmonary nodules is recommended per recent chest CT report.

INDICATION:  ___ female with advanced interstitial lung disease, now
with respiratory failure.

COMPARISON:  ___.

TECHNIQUE:  Single AP radiograph of the chest was obtained.

FINDINGS:  Endotracheal tube is seen with tip approximately 4 cm above the
carina.  A right internal jugular catheter terminates in the upper SVC.  An
intestinal tube traverses below the diaphragm.  Diffuse bilateral opacities
are similar-appearing compared to most recent prior.  There is suggestion of
bilateral pulmonary nodules.  Cardiomegaly and congested mediastinal veins are
noted.  There is no evidence for effusion or pneumothorax. 

IMPRESSION:  Persistent diffuse bilateral opacities, which would be better
evaluated with CT when the patient is clinically stable.

HISTORY:  ___ female with fatigue to rule out a cardiopulmonary
process.

TECHNIQUE:  Single portable AP radiograph of the chest was performed.
Comparison is made with examination of ___.

FINDINGS:

There are multiple ill defined pulmonary nodules consistent with known
bilateral metastases.  The cardiomediastinal silhouette is unremarkable. There
is a right-sided central line with the tip in the distal SVC.

CONCLUSION:  Bilateral pulmonary metastases without evidence of a definite
focal consolidation.

PA AND LATERAL CHEST

INDICATION:  ___ woman with lethargy, failure to thrive.  History of
metastatic renal cell.  Evaluate for pneumonia.

COMPARISON:  ___ and CT chest from ___.

FINDINGS:   A right-sided Port-A-Cath has its tip in the distal SVC. There are
multiple rounded pulmonary nodules bilaterally consistent with known
metastases.  There is no pneumothorax or pleural effusion.  The
cardiomediastinal silhouette is normal.  The aorta is somewhat tortuous. There
are fiducial seeds projecting over the lower thorax. There are cholecystectomy
clips in the right lower quadrant. There is degenerative change in the
thoracic spine.

IMPRESSION:  Bilateral pulmonary metastases, without evidence of superimposed
pneumonia.

HISTORY:  Periprosthetic fracture, now requiring preoperative assessment.  

COMPARISON:  Comparison is made with chest radiographs from ___
and ___.  

FINDINGS:

Supine AP images of the chest.  

The lungs are well expanded.  Multiple calcified and noncalcified opacities
are seen scattered diffusely over the lungs, consistent with pleural plaques
related to asbestos disease.  Given the number of pleural plaques, a small
pulmonary nodule cannot be excluded.  There is no pleural effusion or
pneumothorax.  The cardiomediastinal silhouette is enlarged.  Gas-filled and
distended loops of bowel are seen in the abdomen.  

IMPRESSION:

1. Asbestos related pleural plaques, which might obscure a small pulmonary
nodule. 

2.  Cardiomegaly. 

3.  Distended loops of bowel in the abdomen.

INDICATION:  ___ male with history of metastatic melanoma, now with
recurrent seizures and lethargy, comes here to evaluate for pneumonia.

COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph, last performed on ___ and ___.

FINDINGS:  Frontal and lateral radiographs of the chest redemonstrate a round
calcified pulmonary nodule in the posterior right lung base, unchanged from
multiple priors and consistent with prior granulomatous disease.  A known
enlarged right hilar lymph node seen on CT of ___ likely accounts for the
increased opacity at the right hilum.  A known right mediastinal lymph node
conglomerate accounts for the fullness at the right paratracheal region.  No
pleural effusion, pneumothorax or focal consolidation is present.  The patient
is status post median sternotomy and CABG with wires intact.  The cardiac
silhouette is normal in size.  The mediastinal and hilar contours are
unchanged from the preceding radiograph.

IMPRESSION:  No acute cardiopulmonary process.

CHEST RADIOGRAPH PERFORMED ON ___

___.

CLINICAL HISTORY:  Cough for two months, question cause.

FINDINGS:  PA and lateral views of the chest are provided.  The lungs appear
clear without focal consolidation, effusion, or pneumothorax.  No definite
nodule or mass lesions are seen, though sensitivity of radiograph for small
pulmonary nodules is low.  Cardiomediastinal silhouette is normal.  Bony
structures are intact.  No free air below the right hemidiaphragm.

IMPRESSION:  No signs of pneumonia or other acute findings to account for
patient's chronic cough.

EXAMINATION:  PA and lateral chest radiographs

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with participating in clinical research study  //
rule out TB for clinical research study

TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral

COMPARISON:  PA and lateral chest radiographs dated ___

FINDINGS: 

In comparison to the chest radiographs obtained ___, there is been
interval removal of a Dobhoff tube.  Otherwise no significant changes. A
large, right, plaque-like pleural calcification is unchanged.  Lungs are
otherwise fully expanded and clear without focal consolidation cavitary
lesions, or suspicious pulmonary nodules.  Heart size is normal. 
Cardiomediastinal hilar silhouettes are normal.  No pleural effusion.

IMPRESSION: 

No radiographic evidence of active or latent TB.

INDICATION:  ___ man with a cough x1 week who presents for evaluation.

COMPARISON:  Chest radiographs from ___, ___ and ___.

TECHNIQUE:  PA and lateral radiographs of the chest.

FINDINGS:  The heart size is normal.  The aorta is mildly tortuous.  The hilar
and mediastinal contours are otherwise normal.  There is no pleural effusion
or pneumothorax.  No focal consolidations are seen.  The visualized osseous
structures are unremarkable.

Again seen is a right apical pulmonary nodule, likely a benign calcified
granuloma, unchanged in size since ___.  No new pulmonary nodules
are seen.

IMPRESSION:  

1. No new focal consolidations suggestive of pneumonia.

INDICATION:  Bilateral lower extremity weakness.  Known history of metastatic
colon cancer to the lungs.

TECHNIQUE:  Two views of the chest.

COMPARISON:  None available at ___.

FINDINGS:  No focal opacity to suggest pneumonia is seen.  Several bilateral
pulmonary nodules are noted.  Suture line is noted projecting over the right
upper hemithorax.  No significant pleural effusion or pneumothorax is seen. 
The heart size is normal.  There is some tortuosity of the aorta.  A
left-sided port is in place with tip in the mid SVC.

IMPRESSION:
1.  No radiographic evidence of pneumonia.
2.  Multiple pulmonary nodules, compatible with history of metastatic colon
cancer to the lung.  No prior examinations available for comparison.

EXAMINATION:  CHEST RADIOGRAPH ___

INDICATION:  History: ___ with R arm weakness  // eval infiltrate

TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral

COMPARISON:  ___.

FINDINGS: 

The lungs are well-expanded, with no evidence of pleural effusion, pulmonary
edema, pneumothorax, or focal consolidation. The cardiomediastinal silhouette
is stable.

On the frontal projection, just above the posterior right sixth rib, there is
a linear opacity extending laterally, possibly a vessel, with a 4 mm nodular
density just superior to the rib, not seen on the lateral view.

IMPRESSION: 

No acute cardiopulmonary process. Possible right pulmonary nodule seen on the
frontal view only may be artifactual. Non urgent shallow oblique radiographs
are recommended to resolve this finding.

CHEST RADIOGRAPH PERFORMED ON ___

COMPARISON:  None.

CLINICAL HISTORY:  Bradycardia and cough, question pneumonia or fluid
overload.

FINDINGS:  AP upright portable view of the chest is obtained.  The heart is
markedly enlarged.  There are low lung volumes which limit evaluation.
Somewhat ill-defined opacities in the right upper and lower lung could
represent early pneumonia. An EKG lead abuts one of the opacities in the right
upper lung. There is no overt CHF, evidence of pleural effusion, or
pneumothorax.  Mediastinal contour is unremarkable.  Bony structures appear
grossly intact.

IMPRESSION:  Cardiomegaly without overt CHF.  Two areas of opacity in the
right upper and lower lung could represent pneumonia, though followup to
resolution is advised to exclude underlying pulmonary nodules.

Please note at the time of followup, if possible, a dedicated PA and lateral
view of the chest would be recommended to more thoroughly assess.

EXAMINATION:
Chest:  Frontal and lateral views

INDICATION:  History: ___ with tachycardia  // eval for CHF/pneumonia

TECHNIQUE:  Chest:  Frontal and Lateral

COMPARISON:  ___ CT and ___ chest radiograph

FINDINGS: 

1.6 cm right lower lobe pulmonary nodule was better assessed on recent prior
CT.  Calcified left lower lobe pulmonary nodule is also re- demonstrated. No
new focal consolidation is seen.  There is no pleural effusion or
pneumothorax.  The cardiac and mediastinal silhouettes are grossly stable.

IMPRESSION: 

Right lower lobe pulmonary nodule was better assessed on prior CT.  No new
focal consolidation seen.

CHEST RADIOGRAPH PERFORMED ON ___.

Comparison with prior study from ___.

CLINICAL HISTORY:  ___ woman with weakness.  Evaluate for pneumonia.

FINDINGS:  AP and lateral views of the chest are obtained with patient in the
upright position.  There is a rounded opacity in the left mid lung measuring
1.6 x 1.7 cm which is concerning for pulmonary nodule.  No additional
abnormalities are seen within the chest.  No large pleural effusion or
evidence of pneumothorax.  The heart size is difficult to assess but appears
grossly unremarkable.  The mediastinal contour is stable.  There appears to be
stable prominence of the left pulmonary hilum. The aorta contains
atherosclerotic calcification.  Visualized osseous structures are intact.

IMPRESSION:

Nodular opacity in the left mid lung which measures 1.7 x 1.6 cm, for which CT
of the chest is recommended to further evaluate.

Findings were discussed with Dr. ___ by Dr. ___ on
___ at approximately 7:20 p.m.

EXAMINATION:
Chest:  Frontal and lateral views

INDICATION:  History: ___ with confusion today  // eval pna

TECHNIQUE:  Chest Frontal and Lateral

COMPARISON:  ___

FINDINGS: 

The lungs remain hyperinflated. There is slight blunting of the posterior left
costophrenic angle and a trace pleural effusion is not excluded. There is a
nodular opacity projecting over the left mid lung, measuring approximately 1.1
cm, not seen on the prior study. Cardiac and mediastinal silhouettes are
unremarkable.

IMPRESSION: 

1.1 cm nodular opacity projecting over the left mid lung not seen on the prior
study. Recommend outpatient chest CT for further evaluation for possible
pulmonary nodule.

Slight blunting of the posterior left costophrenic angle may relate to
hyperinflation but trace pleural effusion not excluded.

EXAM:  Chest, single semi-erect AP portable view.

CLINICAL INFORMATION:  Respiratory failure.

COMPARISON:  None.

FINDINGS:  Endotracheal tube is seen terminating approximately 5.7 cm above
the level of the carina.  Enteric tube is seen, distal aspect not included on
the image, though it appears to course below the level of the diaphragm. 
Right upper lobe pulmonary nodule, scarring and emphysematous changes are
better assessed on subsequent CT.  Moderate basilar atelectasis.  No large
pleural effusion or pneumothorax.  Cardiac and mediastinal silhouettes are
unremarkable.

HISTORY:  ___ man with HCC and known adrenal metastases, recently
started on sorafenib, now with new cough; evaluate for infiltrate or effusion.

FINDINGS:  Two views are compared with most recent study of ___, as well as
the interval CECT dated ___.

There is minimal linear scarring or atelectasis involving the left CP angle,
which appears new, but the lungs are otherwise well-inflated and clear,
without focal airspace process.  There is slight rounded LV prominence,
unchanged, but no pulmonary vascular congestion, pleural effusion, or other
evidence of CHF.  No pulmonary nodule or mass, and no pleural effusion is
seen.  There is a gentle thoracolumbar dextroscoliosis, as before, with no
bone destruction.

IMPRESSION:  Minimal linear atelectasis involving the left CP angle, with no
other focal airspace process and no pleural effusion.

PORTABLE CHEST, ___, WITH COMPARISON CT TORSO FROM THE SAME DATE

INDICATION:  Delirium.  Nasogastric tube placement.

FINDINGS:  Nasogastric tube tip terminates within the stomach, but side port
is not well visualized and may be proximal to the GE junction. 8 cm mass in
left upper lobe is highly suspicious for neoplasm. Please see report of CT
torso from same date which also describes additional pulmonary nodules.

EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PA AND LAT)

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with pain in the area of the lower lobe of the
left lung.// Any pulmonary lesions that may be causing pain?

TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral

COMPARISON:  Chest x-ray dated back to ___, ___

FINDINGS: 

Low lung volumes.  Cardiomediastinal and hilar contours are unremarkable.  No
evidence of focal consolidation or pulmonary edema.  At the lateral left
midlung is a 6 mm opacity, grossly unchanged when compared to prior.  No
evidence of pleural effusion or pneumothorax.  Visualized osseous structures
are grossly unremarkable.

IMPRESSION:


1. There is a 6 mm opacity at the lateral left midlung, grossly unchanged when
compared to prior.  The pulmonary nodule is incompletely characterized on
radiograph.
2.  No focal consolidation, pulmonary edema, pleural effusion or pneumothorax.

RECOMMENDATION(S):  A follow-up chest CT is recommended to further
characterize the 6 mm opacity at the lateral left midlung.

NOTIFICATION:  The impression and recommendation above was entered by Dr.
___ on ___ at 15:57 into the Department of Radiology
critical communications system for direct communication to the referring
provider.

PA AND LATERAL CHEST, ___ AT 1558 HOURS.

HISTORY:  History of pulmonary nodules, now representing with shortness of
breath.

COMPARISON:  Multiple priors, the most recent dated ___.

FINDINGS:  Chain sutures are again noted in the right middle lobe.  The lungs
are clear without consolidation or edema.  The previously noted nodular
opacity in the left mid lung has resolved.  No nodules are seen currently. The
mediastinum is unremarkable.  The cardiac silhouette is within normal limits
for size.  No effusion or pneumothorax is seen.  The visualized osseous
structures are unremarkable.

IMPRESSION:  Post-surgical changes in right middle lobe with no acute
pulmonary process.  Previously noted left mid lung zone nodule not seen. 
Please note the patient has had prior CT, which have revealed multiple
radio-occult nodules, presumably due to personal history of prior vasculitis
(Wegner's granulomatosis).

EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)

INDICATION:  ___ with FTT, metastatic metastatic melanoma//tachycardia,
infection

COMPARISON:  CT of the chest from ___

FINDINGS: 

AP portable upright view of the chest.  Diffuse interstitial opacities likely
reflect mild interstitial pulmonary edema.  Pulmonary nodule seen on recent CT
are too small to be visualized.  No large effusion or pneumothorax.  No overt
signs of pneumonia.  Cardiomediastinal silhouette appears grossly within
normal limits.  Imaged bony structures are intact.

IMPRESSION: 

Interstitial pulmonary edema.

INDICATION:  Evaluation of patient with shortness of breath.

COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph from ___ and CT chest from ___.

FINDINGS:  There are bibasilar atelectatic changes.  However, more focal
opacity in the right middle lobe may be representative of a developing right
middle lobe pneumonia.  Previously visualized right apical spiculated nodule
is again identified and continued to follow up as per CT is recommended. 
Multiple other pulmonary nodules previously visualized on CT are better
visualized on prior CT from ___.  Cardiomediastinal silhouette is
normal.  No acute fractures identified.

INDICATION:    Preoperative

TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral

COMPARISON:  No priors

FINDINGS: 

The cardiomediastinal shadow is normal.  Mild unfolding of the aorta. 
Calcification of the aortic arch.  No airspace consolidation.  No suspicious
pulmonary nodules or masses.  Mild coarsening of the bronchovascular markings.
No pleural effusions.  The hila are normal.  Spondylotic changes of the
thoracic spine.

IMPRESSION: 

No acute pleuropulmonary process.

INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with mediastinal mass s/p biopsy with chest
tube s/p pull with small apical pneumothorax// evaluate for pneumothorax

TECHNIQUE:  Portable AP chest

COMPARISON:  Multiple prior chest radiographs, most recent dated ___.

FINDINGS: 

Unchanged low lung volumes.  Right perihilar opacities are unchanged.  No new
pulmonary nodules or areas of focal consolidation.  Increased small right
pleural effusion.  Unchanged small left pleural effusions.  No pneumothorax. 
Cardiomediastinal silhouette is unchanged.

IMPRESSION: 

No pneumothorax.  Increased small right pleural effusion.

INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with newly diagnosed lymphoma, prior CXR w/
pleural effusion, now with acute onset SOB.// ?effusion/pneumothorax

TECHNIQUE:  Portable AP chest

COMPARISON:  Multiple prior chest radiographs, most recent dated ___.

FINDINGS: 

No significant change compared to most recent chest radiograph.  Low lung
volumes and persistent right perihilar opacities.  No new pulmonary nodules or
areas of focal consolidation.  Compared to images from ___,
small bilateral pleural effusions have increased in size.  Compared to chest
radiograph from ___, pleural effusions are unchanged.  Tiny right
apical pneumothorax.  Cardiomediastinal silhouette is unchanged.

IMPRESSION: 

No significant change compared to most recent chest radiograph.  No
pneumothorax.  Increasing small bilateral pleural effusions.  Tiny right
apical pneumothorax.  No new areas of focal consolidation.

EXAMINATION:
Chest:  Frontal and lateral views

INDICATION:  History: ___ with C3 fx s/p fall, ?vertebral artery dissection?//
Pt with C3 fx, ?vertebral artery dissection

HISTORY:  

Lung cancer with right upper quadrant pain.

TECHNIQUE:  PA and lateral views of the chest.

COMPARISON:  Chest CT ___.

FINDINGS:

Volume loss in the right hemithorax is re- demonstrated with persistent
right-sided pleural thickening and loculated pleural fluid, moderate in
amount.  The cardiac silhouette size remains borderline enlarged.  Mediastinal
contour is stable, with numerous mediastinal lymph nodes better assessed on
the previous CT.  Patchy opacity in the right lung base likely reflects a
combination of a dominant right lower lobe lesion, better assessed on the
previous CT, as well as compressive atelectasis.  Additionally, increased
interstitial markings in the right lung base are suggestive of lymphangitic
spread of tumor.  Multiple other smaller pulmonary nodules are noted
throughout the lungs, but are better assessed on the previous CT.  No focal
consolidation or pleural effusion is seen within the left lung.  No
pneumothorax. There are no acute osseous abnormalities.

IMPRESSION:

Overall no significant interval change in comparison to the previous CT. 
Right-sided pleural thickening and loculated moderate size right pleural
effusion, unchanged.  Right basilar patchy opacity reflects a combination of
the dominant right lower lobe lesion and compressive atelectasis.  Increased
interstitial markings in the right lung base also are compatible with likely
lymphangitic spread of tumor.  Multiple pulmonary nodules in both lungs are
better seen on the previous CT.

EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with NSTEMI, COPD, found down in street// eval
for fracture, pna

COMPARISON:  None.

FINDINGS: 

There is background hyperinflation, suggesting background COPD.  There is
probable mild cardiomegaly.  Aorta is minimally unfolded.  Mild prominence of
the hila with a tapered appearance could reflect pulmonary hypertension.

There is possible minimal upper zone redistribution, but no evidence of CHF. 
No focal infiltrate or effusion is identified.

There is a curvilinear lucency projecting over the right upper lung between
the right posterior fourth and fifth ribs.  Although this raises the
possibility of a right upper pneumothorax, vessels are seen projecting beyond
it and this more likely represents artifact due to skin fold.  There is no
associated atelectasis.

Rounded lucency projecting between the anterior fourth and fifth ribs most
likely reflects rib synostosis.  A finding in the lateral right mid lung is
considered less likely.

Abutting the lower left chest wall, overlying the left anterior seventh rib,
there is a 3.8 mm nodular opacity, possibly a small pulmonary nodule.

IMPRESSION: 

Suspect background COPD, with possible pulmonary hypertension.

Mild cardiomegaly.  No CHF, focal infiltrate or effusion is detected.

Curvilinear lucency at right lung apex more likely represents a skin fold than
a pneumothorax.  Clinical correlation is requested.  If there is clinical
concern for pneumothorax, a repeat film, obtained at end expiration of the
respiratory cycle could help for further assessment.

Probable normal variant or old posttraumatic synostosis of the right fourth
and fifth anterior ribs.  Please see comment above.

No displaced rib fractures identified on these lung technique films, to
suggest acute rib injury.

3.8 mm nodule abutting the lower left chest wall.  Further assessment with
nonemergent chest CT is recommended.

RECOMMENDATION(S):  If clinical concern for right pneumothorax, than repeat AP
chest x-ray with low inspiratory volume.

Recommend nonurgent chest CT for further assessment of a 3.8 mm nodule
abutting the lower left chest wall.

INDICATION:  ___ w/ metastatic breast cancer presenting with severe dizziness.

COMPARISON:  ___ and CT of the chest from yesterday.

FINDINGS: 

AP upright and lateral views of the chest provided.

Left chest wall Port-A-Cath is again seen with catheter tip in the region of
the low SVC.  The previously noted right chest tube has been removed.  Several
pulmonary nodules are better assessed on CT from yesterday, the largest in the
retrocardiac region measuring approximately 3.4 x 3.4 cm.  A second nodule in
a right upper lobe measures approximately 16 x 11 mm.  There is blunting of
the right CP angle consistent with a small pleural effusion.  Opacity
projecting along the right medial lung base better characterized as a chest
wall lesion on the CT from yesterday.  No definite signs of a superimposed
pneumonia.  Overall heart size is stable and normal.  Bony structures appear
unchanged.

No signs of pneumonia.  Metastatic burden in the chest better assessed on CT
from 1 day ago.

Similar-appearing right-sided partially loculated pleural effusion.  No
pneumothorax.  Pulmonary nodules better seen on recent CT.

EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PA AND LAT)

INDICATION:  History: ___ with sob  // eval for chf or pna

COMPARISON:  None.

FINDINGS: 

The lungs are hyper inflated, suggesting background COPD.  There is moderate
to moderately severe cardiomegaly.  There are diffusely increased interstitial
markings, of indeterminate acuity.  The possibility of mild right hilar
prominence cannot be excluded.  The left hilum is obscured by overlying
structures.  There is blunting of the costophrenic angles posteriorly,
consistent with small bilateral effusions.  There is a 9.9 mm rounded nodular
opacity in the right cardiophrenic region, not definitively identified on the
lateral view.  No pneumothorax is detected.


IMPRESSION:


1. Probable background COPD.
2. Moderate to moderately severe cardiomegaly.
3. Diffusely increased interstitial markings.  In the appropriate clinical
setting, this could represent CHF and small bilateral effusions are noted. 
However, depending on the clinical presentation, the differential diagnosis
includes other etiologies for increased interstitial markings, including
atypical infection, inflammatory, and neoplastic processes.
4. Possible prominence of the right hilum.  Attention to this area after
resolution of acute symptoms is requested.
5. Nodular opacity in the right cardiophrenic region.  The possibility of a
pulmonary nodule cannot be excluded.  Again, attention to this area after
resolution of acute symptoms is requested.  Unless this proves to be a
calcified granuloma or something on the patient's skin, then further
evaluation with chest CT would be recommended.

EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)

INDICATION:  History: ___ with history of lung cancer presents with anemia,
general weakness

TECHNIQUE:  Portable upright AP view of the chest

COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph ___ and chest CT ___

FINDINGS: 

Lung volumes are low.  Cardiac, mediastinal and hilar contours are unchanged
from the recent chest CT allowing for differences in technique.  Pulmonary
vasculature is not engorged.  Focal opacity within the left lower lobe
partially reflects the known cavitary mass seen on the previous CT, with
probable superimposed infection or atelectasis.  Additionally, multiple
scattered pulmonary nodules seen on prior CT are not as well assessed on the
current exam.  Trace left pleural effusion is present.  No right pleural
effusion or pneumothorax is present.  Innumerable sclerotic metastatic lesions
are again seen within the osseous structures.

IMPRESSION: 

Patchy opacity within the left lower lobe likely reflects a combination of the
patient's known cavitary mass as well as superimposed infection or
atelectasis.  Trace left pleural effusion.  Known bilateral pulmonary nodules
are better assessed on the prior CT.  Re- demonstration of diffuse sclerotic
osseous metastases.

1. Multiple faint focal airspace opacities likely correspond to known
pulmonary metastases.
2. No focal consolidation concerning for pneumonia is detected.

EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PA AND LAT)

INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with alcoholic hepatitis. Has tachycardia and
decreased b/l breath sounds.  // ? source of decreased b/l breath sounds

COMPARISON:  None.

FINDINGS: 

Artifact from the patient's hair overlies the right left lung apices. 
Inspiratory volumes are slightly low.

Probable mild cardiomegaly.   There is bibasilar atelectasis with small
bilateral effusions.  No definite consolidation or infectious infiltrate.  The
mid and upper zones are grossly clear, without infiltrate.  The apices, as
noted, are obscured by overlapping artifact.

There are calcified mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes, suggesting prior
granulomatous disease.  At the right base laterally, there is a small focal
irregularity, which may simply be artifact due to fluid and atelectasis. 
However a focal pulmonary nodule, possibly a calcified granuloma, might also
account for this appearance.

Mild degenerative changes noted in the thoracic spine.

IMPRESSION: 

Small bilateral pleural effusions and bibasilar subsegmental atelectasis. 
Although an infectious infiltrate or area of aspiration pneumonitis cannot be
entirely excluded, the appearance is more suggestive of atelectasis.

Elsewhere, no focal infiltrate or consolidation.  Bilateral apices are
partially obscured.

Probable mild cardiomegaly.

Calcified hilar and mediastinal lymph nodes, consistent with prior
granulomatous disease.

Small focal density at the right base laterally is partially obscured by
surrounding effusion and atelectasis.  Attention to this area on followup
films is recommended to exclude a focal nodule or  calcified granuloma.



RECOMMENDATIONS:  Small focal density at the right base laterally is partially
obscured by surrounding effusion and atelectasis. Attention to this area on
followup films is recommended to exclude a focal nodule or calcified
granuloma.

INDICATION:  Status post pleural procedures.

FINDINGS:  Interval placement of right-sided chest tube with decrease in size
of right pleural effusion, with development of a small right pneumothorax with
apical and basilar components.  Large partially loculated left pleural
effusion has increased in the interval, however.  Bilateral heterogeneous
pulmonary opacities are present, with improvement at the right lung base but
worsening elsewhere in the lungs.  In particular, there is an apparent area of
confluent air space disease in the left upper lobe, difficult to assess due to
adjacent loculated pleural fluid.  Numerous pleural and pulmonary nodules are
again demonstrated consistent with widespread metastatic disease.

effusion or pneumothorax in the right. The patient is status post wedge
resection of the left lower lobe. A chest tube is again noted ending in the
left apex. A previously noted left sided pneumothorax has resolved in the

loculated pleural effusion.  Otherwise, no interval change compared with prior
exam.

EXAMINATION:  CHEST RADIOGRAPH

INDICATION:  Status post fall.  Question rib fracture.

COMPARISON:  None.

TECHNIQUE:  Chest, AP supine view.

FINDINGS: 

The heart is normal in size. The right upper mediastinum shows mild convexity
which is a common finding that is usually associated with tortuosity of the
great of vessels. There is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Projecting
over the right mid lung is a nodular opacity measuring about 1 cm which may
represent a pulmonary nodule versus summation shadow, or perhaps less likely a
nipple shadow. Elsewhere, the lungs appear clear.  No fracture is identified.

IMPRESSION: 

1.  No definite evidence of injury.

2.  Nodular focus, a possible pulmonary nodule, projecting over the right
lower lung. When clinically appropriate, repeat radiography is suggested
including standard PA and lateral views in addition to a PA view with nipple
markers.

These findings were put into the ED dashboard.

INDICATION:  Recent diagnosis of pneumonia, pre bronchoscopy.  Question
interval change.

COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph from ___.

FINDINGS:  Heterogeneous right lung opacification with a mid and upper lung
predominance is slightly decreased.  At the right apex, there is a large round
area of consolidation containing a crescentic lucency.  Given the likely right
lung necrotizing pneumonia seen on CT from ___, this cavitary
lesion could represent an acute infectious process known as "pulmonary
gangrene";  if a chronic cavity has been present in the right apex, mycetoma
should also be considered in the differential diagnosis.  Small bilateral
pleural effusions are unchanged.  An opacity in the left upper lung may be a
focal area of infection or could be a lung nodule.  Diffuse severe emphysema
is again seen.  The left PICC ends in the mid SVC.

IMPRESSION:

1.  Decreased heterogeneous opacification of the right lung which may reflect
a combination of known pneumonia and recently suspected superimposed edema.

2.  Right apical cavitary lesion with intraluminal opacity could reflect
infectious "pulmonary gangrene" if an apical cavity has not been chronically
present.  Alternatively, the chronic presence of an apical cavity would raise
suspicion for mycetoma.

3.  Unchanged small bilateral pleural effusions.

4.  Nodular opacity in the left upper lobe.  Recommend followup after
resolution of patient's acute illness to differentiate between an infectious
process versus a neoplastic pulmonary nodule.

of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.  Evaluate for pneumonia.

right upper lobe nodule is new compared with prior. There is no pneumothorax.

pleuroparenchymal scar.  The heart size is normal.  The mediastinal contours

emphysema related alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

junction.

COMPARISON:  Scout image from PET-CT of ___.

FINDINGS: 

Right internal jugular catheter terminates at the cavoatrial junction.  Heart
is enlarged, and diffuse mediastinal and hilar widening are present, likely
due to a combination of distended vessels and lymph node enlargement. 
Pulmonary nodules and masses have rapidly grown since the prior PET-CT with a
dominant mass in the left lower lobe now measuring approximately 9 cm in
diameter.  New confluent opacities in the right perihilar and basilar region
probably represent a combination of airspace disease and solid masses.  . 
Note is also made of small bilateral pleural effusions which are apparently
new from the prior PET-CT.

IMPRESSION: 

Marked progression have intrathoracic metastatic disease with likely
superimposed acute process such as asymmetrical edema or infectious pneumonia.
Considering the complexity of findings and known history of sarcoma, further
evaluation with chest CT MAY BE HELPFUL.

RECOMMENDATION:

CHEST CT.

INDICATION:  History: ___ with SOB// evaluate for CHF

TECHNIQUE:  Portable chest radiograph performed in the semi-erect position

COMPARISON:  None available

FINDINGS: 

Low lung volumes are demonstrated bilaterally.  The left costophrenic angle is
excluded from the image.

There is pulmonary haziness obscuring the right heart border as well as
interstitial thickening and mild consolidative opacity involving the right
lower and likely middle lobes.  There is hazy opacity of the left retrocardiac
lung.  The lung apices are partially obscured by the overlying soft tissue of
the neck and chin, however no large pneumothorax is demonstrated.  There is a
likely small right pleural effusion.

Dense nodules in the left hilum measure up to 1.4 cm, and could reflect
pulmonary vessels however appear slightly denser than expected.  The heart
size is mildly enlarged which is likely accentuated by low lung volumes.  No
acute osseous abnormality is demonstrated.

IMPRESSION:


1. Opacification of the right lower and middle lobes is suggestive of acute
onset pulmonary edema, infectious focus or less likely severe atelectasis. 
There is underlying small right pleural effusion.  Mild cardiomegaly.
2. Low lung volumes bilaterally.  Bilateral pulmonary central vascular
fullness.  Dense round opacities in the left hilum are slightly denser than
expected for pulmonary vessels.  This could reflect additional component of
central vascular congestion, however pulmonary nodules are not completely
excluded.  Recommend dedicated chest CT which could be obtained in the
nonacute setting.

fracture.  There is a new small nodular opacity at the periphery of the right
mid lung as well as a more confluent pleural opacity at the periphery of the
right base and a possible small right pleural effusion, noting blunting of the
right costophrenic angle.

effusion.  While this could represent pleural effusion with rounded

short-term followup with x-ray or CT to ensure stability.

resolved after nitroglycerin.

COMPARISON:  None.  Reference made to lung bases from the abdomen and pelvis
from ___.

FINDINGS:  Frontal and lateral views of the chest are obtained.  No focal
consolidation is seen.  Trace blunting of posterior left costophrenic angle is
noted which may be due to pleural thickening or a very trace pleural effusion.
No large pleural effusion is seen.  There is no pneumothorax.  No overt
pulmonary edema is seen.  There are calcifications at the aortic knob.  The
cardiac silhouette is not enlarged.  Degenerative changes are seen along the
spine.  Residual contrast is seen in the visualized aspect of the colon (at
the splenic flexure and distal transverse colon).

Degenerative changes of both shoulder joints are noted.

IMPRESSION:  Trace blunting of the posterior left costophrenic angle, may be
due to pleural thickening or a very trace effusion.  No large pleural effusion
seen.  Otherwise, no acute cardiopulmonary abnormality.

Please note the tiny 3-mm right lower lobe pulmonary nodule seen on the prior
CT would not be appreciated on this study and recommendations per that study
remain.

assessment of possible pulmonary nodule.

effusion.  Otherwise, remainder of the examination is grossly unchanged.

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with recently diagnosed renal cell Ca. malignant
pleural effusion s/p thoracentesis ongoing SOB  // eval for fluid
reaccumulation

COMPARISON:  None

FINDINGS: 

Large left pleural effusion is present as well as a extensive bilateral
rounded pleural lesions some of which may reflect loculated pleural fluid and
others may reflect pleural metastatic deposits.  Mediastinal and bilateral
hilar widening are concerning for lymphadenopathy.  Heart size cannot be
accurately assessed due to obscuration of left heart border.  Bilateral
pulmonary nodules are present as well as nonspecific areas of more confluent
opacification in the lower lobes and lingula which may reflect atelectasis and

pneumothorax. Bilateral pleural abnormalities likely due to malignant pleural
disease given history of malignant pleural effusion. Associated intrathoracic
lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules, also highly concerning for metastatic
disease. Correlation with CT imaging is suggested if not already performed.

FRONTAL CHEST RADIOGRAPH

INDICATION:  ___ man with mandible fracture, preoperative radiograph.

COMPARISON:  Not available at the ___.

FINDINGS:  The cardiomediastinal silhouette is normal.  There is no pneumonic
consolidation, pleural effusion or pneumothorax.  Projecting over the left
hemithorax is a rounded 17 mm density, which may represent a confluence of
shadows, however, presence of pulmonary nodule cannot be excluded. There is no
pulmonary edema. Imaged osseous structures are intact.

IMPRESSION:
1.  No radiographic evidence of pneumonia or pulmonary edema.

2.  17-mm rounded density projecting over the left lower hemithorax, which may
be due to confluence of shadows; however, repeat PA and lateral chest
radiograph are recommended to exclude presence of a pulmonary nodule.

HISTORY:  ___ female with sore throat, fever, and productive cough.  

COMPARISON:  None.  

FINDINGS:

Frontal and lateral views of the chest were obtained.  Lung volumes are low,
slightly exaggerating heart size. Cardiomediastinal contours are otherwise
within normal limits.  There is a vague but somewhat rounded opacity
projecting over the left superhilar region seen only on the frontal view.  The
lungs are otherwise clear.  No focal consolidation, pleural effusion, or
pneumothorax.  

IMPRESSION:  Small vague left suprahilar opacity, for which atelectasis versus
potentially a small focus of pulmonary infection could be considered in the
appropriate setting.  Particularly since a pulmonary nodule is not excluded,
however, short-term follow-up repeat PA and lateral chest radiographs are
recommended to reassess within eight weeks.

FINDINGS:

There is stable biapical pleural thickening.  The lungs are over-inflated
consistent with COAD. There is a subtle added density projected over the
anterior aspect of the left 6th rib, this may represent a lesion in the rib or
a pulmonary nodule. There is stable appearance to the left paramediastinal
surgical sutures as well as the surgical clips in the left upper quadrant of
the abdomen.

There is stable appearance to the old healed left clavicle or fracture.  There
are multilevel degenerative changes present in the spine.

CONCLUSION:

1.  Subtle added density projectd over the anterior aspect of the left 6th rib
may represent a lesion in the rib or a pulmonary nodule. Given this patient's
history of a colon cancer, a chest CT is recomended.

2.  Stable left paramediastinal surgical sutures and left upper abdomen
surgical sutures.

TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral

COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph dated ___.

FINDINGS: 

The lungs are hyperexpanded with flattening of the hemidiaphragms, suggesting
emphysema, similar to the prior exam.  A sub-cm, round opacity over the left
anterior third rib is overall similar and appears to have a correlate on the
lateral view.  This could represent a pulmonary nodule or rib lesion.

opacities in the right middle lobe are new from the prior exam, best
appreciated on the lateral view, likely atelectasis.  No pleural effusion or
pneumothorax.

Heart size and extensive aortic knob calcifications are unchanged.

Nonspecific gaseous distension of partially visualized loops of bowel are
similar to the prior exam.

IMPRESSION: 

1.  New right middle lobe streaky opacity is probably atelectasis.

2.  Hyperexpanded lungs suggestive of emphysema.

3.  Sub-centimeter nodule is unchanged and may be in the bones or lungs.  This
could be further evaluated with a non-emergent chest radiograph with shallow
oblique views, or if still unrevealing, a Chest CT.

RECOMMENDATION(S):  A non-emergent chest radiograph with shallow oblique
views, or if still unrevealing, a Chest CT, to further evaluate a left lung or
osseous lesion.

INDICATION:  Chest pain and rapid heart rate, assess for infiltrate.

nodule, though this may be due to a confluence of overlapping structures. 
There is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax. The heart is normal in size. A
rounded contour projecting over the aortic knob is suspicious for a
mediastinal lesion, of which aortic aneurysm is one consideration. 

IMPRESSION:  1. No acute intrathoracic process. 
2. Possible 1 cm nodule in the left upper midlung for which shallow obliques
are recommended.

positioned aorta or anterior mediastinal pathology. If shallow obliques are
obtained for the nodule, this can be assessed at that time as well.
Alternatively CT angiography could be obtained for assessment.

coarctation of the aorta distal to the left subclavian artery and
post-stenontic dilation of the aorta to 4.3 cm. No pulmonary nodule was seen
suggesting the opacity was due to superimposition of normal structures.

deformity of the posterior right eighth rib is again noted and stable.  The
aorta is mildly tortuous but stable with calcified plaque seen at the arch. 
The cardiac silhouette is borderline enlarged but stable.  No effusion or
pneumothorax is noted.  Aside from the above-mentioned bony abnormalities,
there is profound diffuse osteopenia.

IMPRESSION:  Numerous incidental findings namely within the spine as above. 
There is an ill-defined opacity centrally projecting within the lower left
hemithorax.  Given its proximity this may represent callus from a rib fracture
(anterior left fourth rib) however an underlying pulmonary nodule cannot be
entirely excluded.  Consider non-urgent chest CT for further evaluation to
exclude underlying pulmonary nodule.

INDICATION:  ___ year old man with wheeze R lower lung more than L lower lung//
any evidence of pneumonia

TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral

COMPARISON:  Comparison to prior radiograph studies dated ___
and ___.

FINDINGS: 

Cardiomediastinal silhouette is within normal limits.  There is a nodular
density measuring 2.5 x 2 cm at the right lung base which appears new compared
to prior exam and likely represents a nipple shadow.  However, a solid
pulmonary nodule cannot be definitively excluded.  No pneumothorax or pleural
effusion.  No pulmonary vascular congestion.  There is irregularity at the
lateral aspect of the seventh and eighth ribs which could be secondary to
nondisplaced rib fractures.

IMPRESSION:


1. No evidence of pneumonia.
2. Right lung base nodular density likely representing a nipple shadow. 
However, a solid pulmonary nodule cannot be definitively excluded.  Repeat
imaging with nipple markers is recommended.
3. Lateral seventh and eighth rib irregularities may be secondary to
nondisplaced rib fractures.  Correlation with history and physical exam is
recommended.  Dedicated rib series may be helpful if there is further clinical
concern.

equally.  No larger discrete infiltrate is noted.  Lateral and posterior
pleural sinuses are free and there is no evidence of pneumothorax in the

limits.  There exists no prior chest examination or records available for
comparison.

described findings most likely represent secondary metastatic dissemination.

unlikely.  The patient to undergo surgical biopsy.

would recommend correlation with prior chest imaging, if available.

reflect a pulmonary nodule or costochondral calcification.

imaging of the chest if available or obtaining noncontrast chest CT to
evaluate for possible right upper lobe pulmonary nodule.

pneumonia or pulmonary edema.  I think the most likely is intense reaction to
chemotherapy.

since ___, but the consolidative lesion inferior to the large metastasis in
the left midlung is bigger today than it was 3 days ago.  This combination can
be explained by either focal pulmonary hemorrhage or infection and improvement
in generalized inflammation due to chemotherapy or pulmonary edema due to
cardiac decompensation.

Today there is minimal if any right pleural effusion.  No left pleural
effusion or any pneumothorax heart size is normal.

PIC line has been removed.

See FINDINGS above for discussion of acute changes between ___ and ___,
and some subsequent improvement in background interstitial abnormality with
concurrent increase in masslike consolidation in the left lung since ___.

INDICATION:  Right wrist pain and swelling.  Right knee and shoulder pain.

COMPARISON:  Chest radiographs are available from ___.

TECHNIQUE:  Chest, AP view.

FINDINGS: 

There is a dual-lead pacemaker/ICD device that has been placed since the prior
study.  The cardiac, mediastinal and hilar contours appear unchanged.  There
is a vague new nodular opacity, but concerning that measures about 19 mm and
projects superior to the left hilum, a possible pulmonary nodule and
potentially neoplasm.  There is no definite pleural effusion or pneumothorax. 
Moderate rightward convex curvature is centered along the lower thoracic spine
with probably similar multilevel moderate, but incompletely characterized,
degenerative changes along the thoracic spine.  The right shoulder shows
severe degenerative changes including upward subluxation of the humeral head,
which appears to pseudoarticulate with the inferior acromion, an appearance
often associated with substantial rotator cuff pathology.  The bones appear
demineralized.

IMPRESSION: 

1.  No evidence of acute cardiopulmonary disease.

2.  New nodular focus projecting over the left upper lobe, concerning for
possible neoplasm but not optimally assessed with this technique.  Evaluation
initially with either standard PA and lateral radiography in short-term
follow-up is suggested, if feasible, versus consideration of beginning
directly with chest CT.

consolidation.

COMPARISON:  None.

FINDINGS: 

The lungs are relatively hyperinflated No focal consolidation is seen.  There
is mild right apical pleural thickening.  No pleural effusion or pneumothorax
is seen.  The cardiac silhouette is top-normal in size.  The mediastinal
contours are unremarkable.  No pulmonary edema is seen.  No evidence of free
air is seen beneath the diaphragm.

No acute cardiopulmonary process.  Subtle opacity at the right lung apex may
represent mild pleural thickening however, follow-up outpatient chest CT is
recommended to exclude underlying pulmonary nodule.

pulmonary nodule.

EXAMINATION:  Chest radiographs

INDICATION:  ___ with SOB, cough.

TECHNIQUE:  Frontal lateral views of the chest

COMPARISON:  None

FINDINGS: 

The lungs are well expanded.  No focal consolidation.  No pleural effusion or
pneumothorax.  Heart size is normal.  The mediastinal silhouette is
unremarkable.  8 mm rounded nodule projecting over the posterolateral right
eighth rib, which may be partially calcified.

IMPRESSION:


1. No evidence of an acute cardiopulmonary abnormality.
2. 8 mm rounded nodule projecting over the posterolateral right eighth rib,
unable to distinguish between osseous or pulmonary origin with consideration
for a rib bone island or pulmonary nodule.  Recommend shallow oblique chest
radiographs to better assess nodule location.

RECOMMENDATION(S):  8 mm rounded nodule projecting over the posterolateral
right eighth rib, unable to distinguish between osseous or pulmonary origin
with consideration for a rib bone island or a pulmonary nodule.  Recommend
shallow oblique chest radiographs to better assess nodule location.

right pleural effusion is seen.  There is no evidence of pneumothorax.  The

Moderate to large left pleural effusion with overlying atelectasis.

Rounded right perihilar opacity appears to project anteriorly on the lateral
view, raising concern for pulmonary nodule/mass.  Recommend further evaluation
with non emergent chest CT.

INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with ESRD, failed renal transplant, being
worked up for another renal transplant  // Assess for any lesions,
abnormalities

TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral

COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph from ___.

FINDINGS: 

The lungs are well expanded.  A small nodular opacity in the left upper lung
is not well seen on previous radiographs.  Hila and cardiomediastinal contours
and pleural surfaces are normal.  The alternating bands of sclerosis and
lucency in the vertebral bodies of the spine suggest renal osteodystrophy.

IMPRESSION:


1. Left upper lung nodular opacity could represent overlapping osseous and
vascular structures or a pulmonary nodule.  Apical lordotic chest radiographic
views are recommended to clarify.
2. Likely renal osteodystrophy.

RECOMMENDATION(S):  Apical lordotic chest radiographic views are recommended
to clarify.

INDICATION:  ___ woman with fever status post chemotherapy.

COMPARISON:  CT abdomen and pelvis ___.

FINDINGS:  Frontal and lateral chest radiographs were obtained.  The
cardiomediastinal and hilar contours are within normal limits.  A right chest
wall Port-A-Cath ends at the level of the mid SVC.  The lung volumes are low. 
There is focal consolidation involving the left upper lobe, given the lack of
prior comparisons, this is concerning for an acute infectious process.  No
pleural effusion or pneumothorax is identified. Bibasal nodular opacities,
correspond to the known pulmonary metastatic nodules in the lung bases.

IMPRESSION:

1.  Left upper lobe consolidation, concerning for pneumonia.  However, there
are no comparisons available of this area to assess chronicity of this
finding.  In setting of fever, must be presumed acute.

2.  Multiple subcentimeter pulmonary nodules throughout both lungs, in keeping
with the history of metastatic pancreatic cancer.

INDICATION:  Fever.

PA AND LATERAL CHEST RADIOGRAPH.

COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph, ___.

FINDINGS:  Stable appearance to a right-sided central access catheter.  There
are numerous bilateral rounded pulmonary opacities compatible with patient's
known metastatic pancreatic cancer.  There is unchanged appearance to a left
upper lobe opacity.  There is minimal increased posterior dependent
atelectasis.  Cardiac silhouette, hilar and mediastinal contours appear
stable.  No pneumothorax or pleural fluid is present.

IMPRESSION:
1.  Stable diffuse pulmonary nodules compatible with metastatic disease.

2.  Left upper lobe opacity which may reflect scarring or atelectasis;
however, no new focal opacities suggestive of pneumonia.

INDICATION:  History: ___ with fever, cough// pna?

TECHNIQUE:  Chest:  Frontal and Lateral

COMPARISON:  Chest CT from ___ and chest radiograph from ___

FINDINGS: 

The lungs are hyperinflated due to emphysema.  Chest CT in ___ showed
segmental consolidation at the right lung base adjacent to a region of
bronchiectasis, accompanied by pleural effusion, little changed today.  There
were several small pulmonary nodules, some calcified.  Today there are new
larger nodular opacities in the left lower lung, new peribronchial
opacification on the left, probably a multifocal infection.  There is also new
pulmonary vascular congestion, mild pulmonary edema and slight increase in
heart size, exaggerated by differences in radiographic technique.

IMPRESSION:


1. Multifocal infection, could be due to opportunistic infection, unusual
pathogen, or organisms related to chronic suppurative bronchiectasis.
2. Chronic right lower lobe consolidation, probably related to bronchiectasis,
accompanied by persistent small right pleural effusion.
3. New mild congestive heart failure.

INDICATION:  ___ male preop for repair of right-sided hip fracture.

COMPARISONS:  None.

FINDINGS:  There is elevation of the right minor fissure with relative
radiolucency of the right lower lobe compared to the contralateral side. There
is right upper lobe near-collapse/atelectasis.  A smooth contour is noted just
superior to the expected location of the right hilum and is concerning for a
right hilar mass.  Tenting of the right hemidiaphragm and elevation of the
minor fissure represent evidence of right upper lobe volume loss.    The
findings repreent a "reverse S-Sign of Golden."  A small nodular density
projecting just lateral to the left hilus and may represent a vessel on end or
a pulmonary nodule. The remainder of the lungs are clear. There is no
consolidation. There are no pleural effusions. The heart is top normal in size
and the aorta is mildly unfolded. Note is also made of aortic calcifications.

IMPRESSION:  Right hilar obstructive mass resulting in the right upper lobe
atelectasis/collapse. These findings are concerning for underlying lung
carcinoma, particularly given the osseous findings on subsequent radiographs.
Possible nodular density within the left lung as well. A chest CT with
contrast is recommended to further evaluate these findings.

examination can be seen with small airway disease and/or bronchitis in the
appropriate clinical setting.
